name: 1613_E. Crazy Robot
description:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns. Each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. Upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
prompt:
There is a grid made up of n rows and m columns, and each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab, and all the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked. A crazy robot has escaped from this lab, and the robot is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", each meaning moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction. However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command and upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command, ensuring the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction, otherwise, it will do nothing. We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be compelled to reach the lab starting from this cell. That is, after each move of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what alternative directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab. Make sure to optimize the solution for large grids to handle up to 1000x1000 cells efficiently.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

1 9

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.

There is a grid made up of n rows and m columns, and each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab, and all the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked. A crazy robot has escaped from this lab, and the robot is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", each meaning moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction. However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command and upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command, ensuring the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction, otherwise, it will do nothing. We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be compelled to reach the lab starting from this cell. That is, after each move of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what alternative directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab. Make sure to optimize the solution for large grids to handle up to 1000x1000 cells efficiently.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types:

The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells that can be compelled to reach the lab in each test case grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of test case grids.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        reachable[lab_position[0]][lab_position[1]] = True

        # Directions for BFS: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.' and not reachable[nx][ny]:
                    # Check if the cell can be compelled to reach the lab
                    free_directions = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_directions += 1

                    if free_directions <= 1:
                        reachable[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Prepare the result grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))

        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []

    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append(grid)

# Call the function

# Output interface

    for line in result:
        print(line)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which cells can force the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        visited[lab_position[0]][lab_position[1]] = True

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # Perform BFS
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and not visited[nx][ny] and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_directions = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_directions += 1

                    # If only one free direction, it can be forced to the lab
                    if free_directions <= 1:
                        visited[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Mark reachable cells with '+'
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and visited[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))

        results.append(result_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can compel the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if this cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))
                    elif grid[nx][ny] == 'L':
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be compelled to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of modified grids with reachable cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be compelled to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can force the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: up, down, left, right
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        # BFS from the lab position
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set()
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it is reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        reachable.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can compel the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with free cells marked where the robot can be forced to reach the lab.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a mutable list of lists
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if this cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))
                    elif grid[nx][ny] == 'L':
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can compel the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int, lab_pos: Tuple[int, int]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            grid (List[str]): The grid for the current test case.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            lab_pos (Tuple[int, int]): Position of the lab in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        visited = set([lab_pos])
        result_grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be compelled to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            result_grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return [''.join(row) for row in result_grid]

    results = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_pos = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab position
        modified_grid = bfs(grid, n, m, lab_pos)
        results.append(modified_grid)

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append(grid)

    # Output interface
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # BFS to find reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set()
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    # If the cell has at most one free neighbor, it is reachable
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        reachable.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells that can force the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List of modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int, lab_pos: Tuple[int, int]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            grid: The grid representation of the test case.
            n: Number of rows in the grid.
            m: Number of columns in the grid.
            lab_pos: Position of the lab in the grid.

        Returns:
            Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque([lab_pos])
        visited = set([lab_pos])
        result_grid = [list(row) for row in grid]

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            result_grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return [''.join(row) for row in result_grid]

    result = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        lab_pos = None

        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_pos = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_pos:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab position
        modified_grid = bfs(grid, n, m, lab_pos)
        result.append(modified_grid)

    return result

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append(grid)

# Output interface
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[List[str]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[List[str]]): List of grids for each test case.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            grid (List[str]): The grid for the current test case.
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for moving in the grid
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]

        # Initialize BFS
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        reachable = set()

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            # Check all possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if this cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            reachable.add((nx, ny))
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Modify the grid to mark reachable cells
        modified_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if (i, j) in reachable:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            modified_grid.append(''.join(row))

        return modified_grid

    results = []
    for grid in test_cases:
        n = len(grid)
        m = len(grid[0])
        results.append(bfs(grid, n, m))

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()

    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]
        test_cases.append(grid)
        index += n + 1

    # Call the function
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

requirement analysis:
The problem requires determining which free cells in a grid can lead a robot to a lab, given the robot's unpredictable movement. The solution must efficiently handle large grids and multiple test cases, ensuring the output format is correct.
requirement pool:
- Optimize the solution for large grids up to 1000x1000 cells.
- Ensure the output format is correct for multiple test cases.
- Handle edge cases where the robot cannot reach the lab.
- Provide clear documentation and comments in the code.
- Implement additional features for user interaction.
We will use a Breadth-First Search (BFS) algorithm starting from the lab to determine which free cells can be compelled to reach the lab. This approach is efficient for large grids and ensures that we explore all possible paths from the lab to free cells. We will mark cells that can reach the lab with a '+'. The BFS will be implemented using a queue to explore each cell's neighbors, ensuring that we only visit each cell once.

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
